references.R99WIL02SEGP: Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.

habitat_description: The habitat associations of the Saxicoline Deermouse (Peromyscus gratus; also called Osgoods’ Mouse) are not well described.  Wilson and Ruff (1999) described it as having the most diverse habitat associations of any mountain rodent, although it is usually associated with rocky areas.  Those authors write that it “may prefer foothills where juniper, pinyon, oak, or other shrubby vegetation occurs”, but “it has also been reported from 1829-3110 m in open valleys, cultivated land, grassland, yucca-mesquite, humid sub-tropical forests, and cool coniferous forest on mountaintops (Wilson and Ruff 1999).
